p: Microstructural features, such as grain boundaries or precipitates, also lead to variations in the hit density on the detector. These variations are caused by the local magnification effect [ 2, 10, 11] that appear due to irregularities developing in the local curvature of the specimen. Indeed, as the electrostatic field necessary to provoke the field evaporation depends on the local environment of the evaporating atom [ 12], the evaporation field of various phases is different, which leads to the appearance of local curvature and hence magnification. Grain boundaries are defective regions in the materialâ€™s microstructure, and as such can usually be observed on the detector hit map via the hit density modification they induce locally.
